newsitem.title: USA: Cold weather hampers Minnesota crop development.
newsitem.headline: Cold weather hampers Minnesota crop development.

text.p: Spring planting made rapid progress in the week ended Sunday but low temperatures hindered crop development, according to the Minnesota Agricultural Statistics Service.
Spring wheat was 43 percent planted, down from the five-year average of 68 percent. The crop was 15 percent emerged, against 40 percent on average.

Corn was 92 percent planted, above the average of 69 percent and the fastest pace in nine years. But only 14 percent had emerged, versus the 24 percent average. Soybeans were 57 percent planted, versus the average of 34 percent.
Sugarbeets were 82 percent planted, versus 76 average.
"Cool air dominated over the state and kept soils from warming up," the report said. "Not only warmer temperatures but more moisture is needed for plant growth to resume a normal pattern."
Topsoil moisture was rated two percent very short, 14 percent short, 71 percent adequate and 13 percent surplus.
Pasture was rated five percent very poor, 27 percent poor, 40 percent fair, 26 percent good and two percent excellent.
